title: Wilhelm Maurenbrecher
text:
Karl Peter Wilhelm Maurenbrecher (21 December 18386 November 1892, <a href="Leipzig">Leipzig</a>) was a German historian.
He was born in <a href="Bonn">Bonn</a> and studied in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> and <a href="Munich">Munich</a> under <a href="Leopold%20von%20Ranke">Leopold von Ranke</a> and <a href="Heinrich%20von%20Sybel">Heinrich von Sybel</a>, being especially influenced by the latter historian. After conducting research work at <a href="Simancas">Simancas</a> in <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, he successively became an associate and full professor of history at the <a href="University%20of%20Dorpat">University of Dorpat</a> (1867).
Afterwards, he attained professorships in history at <a href="University%20of%20K%C3%B6nigsberg">Königsberg</a> (1869), <a href="University%20of%20Bonn">Bonn</a> (1877) and <a href="University%20of%20Leipzig">Leipzig</a> (1884), where he was successor to his late friend <a href="Carl%20von%20Noorden">Carl von Noorden</a>.
As a Protestant historian, Maurenbrecher felt an obligation to treat Catholic history objectively. He shared Ranke's views in regards to the common origin of the <a href="Protestant%20Reformation">Protestant</a> and <a href="Catholic%20Reformation">Catholic Reformation</a>s. He chose the term "Catholic Reformation" as an indication of it being a positive tendency of reform rather than a defensive reaction to the Protestant Reformation. Maurenbrecher depicted the Dutch scholar <a href="Erasmus">Erasmus</a> as a pioneer and proponent of Catholic reform.
